text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with a crispy basket burrito that's
right it might look like a tostada or a
taco salad and that's because it is
basically the same thing but that's how
i'm branding this revolutionary method
for making crispy baked tortilla bowls
you see up until this point you needed
an industrial-strength fryer and
especially shaped basket to make these
but after several minutes of intense
research and development i came up with
a method for doing these in the oven and
this is how we do it and first up since
we're not taking the tortilla to the oil
we need to take the oil to the tortilla
so what we'll do is brush some vegetable
oil on both sides not too too much but
we do want both sides covered and in
case you're wondering I'm just using
your basic standard flour tortillas here
and even though they didn't really look
like it it said whole-wheat flour on the
package but anyway I think any kind of
flour tortilla about eight to eight and
half inches across will work here and
then once that's been accomplished we
can move on to the forming of these
which we'll do on a sheet pan with the
help of a ramekin and ideally we're
gonna use something that has about half
the diameter of the tortilla we're gonna
shape and what we'll do with the ramekin
flipped over is center our tortilla over
the top and give it a little bit of an
initial pressing down with our hands at
which point we'll take a piece of
doubled up aluminum foil that's about
the same size as the tortilla and we'll
press that over the top and kind of
scrunch it together like this and as you
can see when we flip that over
it should fairly effectively hold that
tortilla in position and then we'll sort
of go around and bring that foil in
positioning it just below the edge of
the tortilla and that is pretty much it
for the shaping phase okay so not too
difficult and I went ahead and did that
one more time since I'm gonna make two
and then what we'll do once our baskets
are successfully shaped is transfer
those into the center of a 375 degree
oven but just for five minutes okay this
first baking is just to get them to hold
their shape enough so we can remove the
ramekin
which is what we're gonna do as soon as
we pull these out and the reason we need
to pull that ramekin out is because the
inside will never crisp up with that in
there and then what we'll do once those
are sans ramekin is go ahead and pop
them back in the oven
still at 375 for another five minutes at
which point if everything's gone
according to plan they should look
something like this and at this point we
have to perform the most critical step
the old flip and protect and what that
means is will carefully remove our
tortilla from the foil and then sort of
flatten it out as shown by the way don't
burn yourself because I'll get blamed
and then once we've flattened out our
foil we will place our tortilla basket
back on the foil but inverted okay so
that's the flip now we're going to go
around and do the protect what we'll do
is bring that foil back in but just
around the bottom and the reason for
this is because that edge is already
browning and we want to protect that
from overcooking while the rest of this
cooks through so we'll go ahead and give
those a flip and then protect the bottom
of the foil as shown at which point
we're gonna transfer those back into the
oven but this time we'll let them go for
about eight to 10 minutes or until
they're beautifully browned and looking
something like this and by this point
they should be pretty crispy but as I've
taught you before there's no money in
guessing so let's give those a quick
test because as you know fork don't line
so those were pretty crispy and we
probably could have let those cool and
use them but what I like to do is
actually put them back in one more time
so what we'll do is give those one more
flip because when they were upside down
that inside kind of traps the moisture
and if we put them back in once more in
this position that inside is going to
dry up a little more and they will be
even more crispy not to mention even a
more beautiful deeper golden-brown but
be careful if you forget these for a few
extra minutes they might burn which
would be very disappointing and
extremely lame so I'm going to go ahead
and pop those back in for maybe three to
five more minutes at which point we
should be looking at our final product
okay we really do want to push the
envelope on the brownness around the top
without going from golden brown to
golden black so these are looking
absolutely perfect
at this point we'll transfer those to a
rack to cool completely let them cool
all the way down to room temp okay
believe it or not they do not reach
their full crispy potential until
they're cooled but once those have
cooled down we can move on to building
the perfect crispy basket burrito which
is I've already admitted is really just
the same thing as a tostada or a taco
salad oh by the way if this tortilla
looks a little different than the two
you just saw it is I did a few different
batches and of course picked out what I
thought was the coolest for these final
shots but anyways you can see I'm gonna
go ahead and start building my basket
burrito with some shredded lettuce and
pinto beans of course some shredded
cheddar cheese never hurts and then as
far as meat goes I'm gonna go with some
carnitas that I shredded and crisped up
in a pan and maybe a little too crisp if
that's even a thing and then after the
meat I highly recommend we put on some
kind of sauce or salsa I went with a
green tomatillo that I had left over
from something else but our salsa cruda
recipe would work perfect here as with
any of our salsa recipes those choices
of course are up to you you are after
all the Glenn Miller of your filler and
speaking of in the mood I was also in
the mood for some red onions and
tomatoes and by the way a little
presentation tip let everything fall
naturally okay it always looks better if
you don't try to arrange the ingredients
unless they clump up in one spot then
maybe just move those over but anyway
let me go ahead and finish up with some
sour cream as well as some freshly
picked cilantro leaves and I would
definitely have also put some avocado
but I had that for breakfast on some
toast so that was not an option but
anyway that's it my crispy basket
burrito is done and looking like
something that any reasonable person
would want to eat which I did and it was
amazing and of course we've all heard
that old saying you can't have your
crispy basket burrito and eat it too so
while using the fork with one hand we'll
go ahead and break out pieces of that
crispy tortilla with the other and
either crumble them in or use them to
scoop or both
and I believe I already mentioned in the
last video how fun it is to eat at one
of these but let me say it again it's so
fun so I really was happy with how these
came out and that I was able to figure
out a technique that does not require a
deep fryer and really a pretty easy
technique at that I mean sure it does
take a little bit of time but what
doesn't so regardless of what you stuff
in deers I really do hope you give these
a try soon head over to food whooshes
dot-com for all the ingredient amounts
of more info as usual and as always
enjoy
[Music]
